channel.title: List and Array
channel.description: Can someone tell me the difference between List (LinkedList, ArrayList) and Arrays (Arrays of Objects)? Also, when would you use List over Arrays and vice versa?

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I was comparing it to an array[] and a list. Even if you always added to the start of the array it would use less memory and thus be faster as no need to gc() as much.

Read full topic

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:25, topic:218100”]ArrayList is better when adding objects, regardless of position.

The reason is that the underlying array may be bigger than the number of elements in it. Every time you add an element to the array you have to create a new one. With arraylist however you can use the empty spaces at the end.[/quote]

your logic only works if you’re adding to the end of an array list,
if you add somewhere in the middle, the class has to shift a lot of elements up one space in the array

it takes more time the lower down in the array you add,
if you add to position 0, it has to shift the entire array up, if you add to 12, it has to shift the size of the array - 12
if you add to the end, it obviously has to shift no elements,

with a linked list, you have to create a new Element instance and switch some pointers around,

also with the ArrayList adding to the end, it will still have to resize it eventually,

add
add
resize array and add
add
add
add
add
resize array and add
add
add
add
add
add
resize array and add

obviously the add takes much less time then the resize and add

with a linked list its more like,
new Element, copy pointers
new Element, copy pointers
new Element, copy pointers
new Element, copy pointers…

another thing is, linked list uses more heap memory, cause it has to make a new instance of private class Element every time, and a size field, and head and tail field,
with ArrayList, you only store the array and size

Read full topic

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

ArrayList is better when adding objects, regardless of position.

The reason is that the underlying array may be bigger than the number of elements in it. Every time you add an element to the array you have to create a new one. With arraylist however you can use the empty spaces at the end.

Read full topic

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Oh. I understand now how you are comparing them; it doesn’t matter about the size of the objects being held, but by the way they are going to get used. Nice, alright ty lol

Read full topic

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:22, topic:218100”]Say, I have an Array of Strings, which one would be quicker.

And then say I have an Array of Sockets, which one would be quicker.[/quote]
It won’t matter, you can’t compare them like that.

It depends on how they are going to be used. To access a certain thing an array you need to iterate through it, and check for it, with perhaps an ArrayList you can just access it by get()…

Read full topic

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

its good for some stuff, bad for other stuff.
most of the pros and cons are outlined here

look at it this way, if one completely failed then sun wouldnt bother to write it in the first place.

yes its bad for indexing,
i could say ArrayList fails because its bad for adding/removing, you make an entire new array and have to copy everything into the new one.
thats also added overhead

but obviously, thats not a reason ArrayList fails, they are both good in their own situation. So stop bashing LinkedList

EDIT: frank_ that obviuosly depends on what kind of list you want, and what you want it to do

Read full topic

item.description:

if you just want a list, dont use the java.util.LinkedList implementation, same goes for nearly everything

item.title: List and Array
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:8, topic:218100”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=286606.msg2321332#msg2321332 date=1215508743]

by copying me

I am yet to see you post that…
[/quote]

you must be walking around with your eyes shut
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,283041.msg2297789.html#msg2297789

i disagree though, i quite like LinkedList, i fail to see how its bloated, and it seems to fit more situations of mine then ArrayList does,

so no Yz85Racer you are wrong[/quote]
Sorry but frank_ showed me before.

In my opinion LinkedList fails because it has added overhead compared to perhaps an array for each one of its elements. if I can remember correctly the LinkedList has bad access by index… Since I don’t even think you can generify a LinkedList, it has to cater every data structure.

Also, just because it fits from where you believe it works best, does not mean I am wrong. If it fits more of the situations from you then use it for all I care.

Also, off-topic: Can you stop putting commas after every sentence? It is really annoying to read.

Read full topic
